events.originalText: The Belgian government imposed a four-day security lockdown in Brussels based on information about potential terrorist attacks.
events.subtitle: 2015 Brussels lockdown
events.headline: Brussels under four-day security lockdown due to potential terrorist attacks

events.originalText: A remote-controlled bomb exploded on a bus in Tel Aviv, Israel, injuring at least 28 people on board.
events.subtitle: 2012 Tel Aviv bus bombing
events.headline: Remote-controlled bomb explodes on bus in Tel Aviv, injuring 28

events.originalText: An explosion in a coal mine in Heilongjiang, China, killed 108 miners.
events.subtitle: 2009 Heilongjiang mine explosion
events.headline: Explosion in coal mine in Heilongjiang, China, kills 108 miners

events.originalText: "God Defend New Zealand" became New Zealand's second national anthem, on equal standing with "God Save the King", which had been the traditional anthem since 1840.
events.subtitle: God Defend New Zealand
events.headline: New Zealand adopts 'God Defend New Zealand' as second national anthem

events.originalText: Bombs exploded in two pubs in central Birmingham, England, killing 21 people and leading to the imprisonment of six people who were later exonerated.
events.subtitle: Birmingham pub bombings
events.headline: Bombs in two pubs in Birmingham kill 21, leading to wrongful imprisonment

events.originalText: Vietnam War: American forces raided the North Vietnamese Sơn Tây prison camp in an attempt to rescue 61 American POWs who were thought to be held there.
events.subtitle: Vietnam War
events.headline: American forces raid North Vietnamese prison camp in rescue attempt

events.originalText: The Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge (pictured), connecting Staten Island and Brooklyn in New York City, opened to traffic as the longest suspension bridge in the world at the time.
events.subtitle: Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge
events.headline: Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge opens in New York City as longest suspension bridge

events.originalText: La Ronde (pictured), the first revolving restaurant in the United States, was inaugurated.
events.subtitle: La Ronde (restaurant)
events.headline: La Ronde, first revolving restaurant in the US, inaugurated

events.originalText: American disc jockey Alan Freed (pictured), who popularized the term rock and roll, was fired from WABC-AM for his role in the payola scandal.
events.subtitle: Disc jockey
events.headline: DJ Alan Freed fired for role in payola scandal

events.originalText: Two trains collided near Valemount, Canada, killing 21 people; the subsequent trial brought future prime minister John Diefenbaker to greater political attention.
events.subtitle: Canoe River train crash
events.headline: Train collision near Valemount, Canada, kills 21

events.originalText: Manzanar, a camp in California for the internment of Japanese Americans during World War II, was closed.
events.subtitle: Manzanar
events.headline: Manzanar camp for Japanese Americans closed in California

events.originalText: Rebecca Latimer Felton became the first woman to serve in the United States Senate, albeit for only one day.
events.subtitle: Rebecca Latimer Felton
events.headline: Rebecca Latimer Felton serves as first woman in US Senate for one day

events.originalText: Irish War of Independence: On Bloody Sunday in Dublin, the IRA assassinated a group of British intelligence agents, and British forces killed 14 civilians at a Gaelic football match at Croke Park.
events.subtitle: Irish War of Independence
events.headline: Bloody Sunday in Dublin: IRA assassinations and British forces kill civilians

events.originalText: First Sino-Japanese War: After capturing the Chinese city of Port Arthur, the Japanese army began a massacre of the city's soldiers and civilians.
events.subtitle: First Sino-Japanese War
events.headline: Japanese army begins massacre in Port Arthur after capturing city

events.originalText: Thomas Edison announced his invention of the phonograph, a device able to record and play sound.
events.subtitle: Thomas Edison
events.headline: Thomas Edison announces invention of phonograph

events.originalText: The Mayflower Compact, the first governing document of the Plymouth Colony, was signed by 41 of the Mayflower's passengers while the ship was anchored in what is now Provincetown Harbor.
events.subtitle: Mayflower Compact
events.headline: Mayflower Compact signed by passengers in Provincetown Harbor

events.originalText: Turco-Mongol conqueror Timur captured and sacked the Georgian capital Tbilisi and forced King Bagrat V to convert to Islam.
events.subtitle: Turco-Mongol tradition
events.headline: Timur captures Tbilisi, forces King Bagrat V to convert to Islam
